entry.title: The Integration of SAP Business Data Cloud and Customer Data Platform Multiplies the Value
entry.content:
In every industry, data lives in many places: applications, data lakes, warehouses, and partner ecosystems. The challenge isn’t just collecting it; it’s understanding, governing, and activating it in business context without endless copying and re-engineering.  SAP Business Data Cloud  addresses this challenge by giving you a governed, business-ready data foundation that connects SAP and non-SAP sources, preserves business meaning, and makes data easy to use across analytics and AI. 

When you publish curated, consent-aware data products from SAP Business Data Cloud to SAP Customer Data Platform (CDP), you turn that foundation into real-time engagement, personalization, and growth, while preserving governance and trust

 

 

 

 

 

 

What SAP Business Data Cloud does 

Business Data Cloud unifies access to SAP and non-SAP data and lets you model it with business semantics (master data, measures, relationships). It brings centralized governance (catalog, lineage, policies, masking) and a federated data fabric to minimize unnecessary copies. The result is an analytics- and AI-ready layer you can operationalize via APIs, events, and lifecycle controls at enterprise scale.

What SAP Customer Data Platform does 

CDP ingests batch and streaming data from web/mobile, commerce, CRM, service, and adtech/martech. It resolves identities into unified person or account profiles, models profiles and events with relationships, and enforces consent and purpose-based policies. Teams build segments using attributes and behaviors, activate them to channels in batch or near real time, and govern usage with roles, lineage, and monitoring. CDP also exposes APIs and supports importing predictive scores to enrich engagement.

Why Publish SAP Business Data Cloud data to SAP Customer Data Platform

  • Richer, governed context: Share curated customer, order, product, and service attributes so CDP segments reflect true business semantics (for example, lifecycle stage, CLV).
  • Consistent, compliant activation: Carry consent and standardized definitions (VIP, churn risk, eligibility) into every channel to reduce drift and ensure compliant use.
  • Faster time to value: Publish ready-to-use data products so marketing, sales, and service can build segments and journeys without re-engineering upstream data.

How it works in practice (Business Data Cloud → CDP)

  • Prepare governed data products in Business Data Cloud, tagging PII, consent, and purpose metadata.
  • Deliver via secure connectors, APIs, or scheduled exports; use incremental updates or events for freshness.
  • Configure CDP ingestion and identity rules, map schemas, and apply data minimization on ingest.
  • Build segments, activate to destinations, and where supported, feed engagement outcomes back to Business Data Cloud for continuous improvement.

Example use cases

  • Hyper-personalized campaigns: Target offers using eligibility rules and product hierarchies; CDP activates across channels while honoring consent.
  • Churn prevention: Publish churn scores and service history; CDP triggers save-offers and captures outcomes for model tuning.
  • B2B account-based engagement: Share account intent and entitlements; CDP unifies contacts-to-account, segments by buying center, and coordinates outreach.

More info

Suggested learning.sap.com resources and what to look for:

  • Exploring SAP Customer Data Platform Essentials 
  • Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud 

Official product documentation

  • Administering SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP Customer Data Platform Integration Guide

entry.title: How to call AS ABAP from SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Introduction

For communication between SAP systems based on AS ABAP, RFC connections are the standard method. For example, when extracting from SAP ERP, the SAP BW system first launches the extractor in the source system via a BW->ERP RFC connection. The source system then returns the data collected by the extractor via an ERP->BW RFC connection.

For SAP Datasphere (hereinafter referred to as DSP), the natural successor to this approach is the BW Bridge use. However, not all projects justify using BW Bridge in terms of system landscape, architecture, project scope, and implementation costs.

This blog proposes an approach that allows DSP to execute code in a system running AS ABAP (without using BW Bridge). We will call this code as target code. The idea is to leverage CDS functionality known such as Virtual Elements. A Virtual Element is a field in a CDS View Entity, specifically defined using annotations. This field is not retrieved from the database table level and is not calculated by formulas within the CDS View itself. Instead, accessing the CDS View triggers execution of specialized ABAP code that implements the calculation logic for this field. For BW specialists this may remember well-known virtual characteristics and key figures. On the other hand, the CDS View is an object accessible to DSPs, for example, as a Source for Data Flow. Thus, by running Data Flow Run on the DSP side, we automatically initiate execution of the code that calculates the Virtual Element values ​​in AS ABAP. We can, in turn, include calls of any desired programs, functional modules, or class methods to this code—that is, achieve the execution of the target code.

Unfortunately, this approach has one significant drawback that complicates its implementation: Virtual elements are only function within OData services generated from CDS views. This means that we cannot use connections of type SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP ABAP, or SAP BW on the DSP side. You will need to create a Generic OData connection.

Implementation plan is following:

  1. Create a CDS View Entity in S/4HANA using a Virtual Element.
  2. Create an ABAP class that implements the calculation of this Virtual Element. The class code will include the target code call.
  3. Register and test the OData Service.
  4. Review the permissions required for the technical user on whose behalf the connection will be made. These permissions should be broader than the standard permissions for connections of type SAP S/4HANA On-Premise or SAP ABAP.
  5. Notes regarding creating a Generic OData connection in DSP.
  6. Create a simple Data Flow in DSP using the OData connection to the created CDS View. Running this Data Flow (manually, scheduled, or as part of a Task Chain) will trigger our target code in S/4HANA.

CDS View Entity with Virtual Element

We will create a dummy CDS View. It doesn't need to provide any meaningful data. We only need the ability to add a Virtual Element field to it. Therefore, as an example, we'll use a selection from the TKA01 (Controlling Areas) table. Typically, a single Controlling Area with a value of 1000 is used. Based on this assumption, we'll create the CDS View. Of course, you can use other selections that are guaranteed to return a single record in your system. The following code is proposed:

@EndUserText.label: 'CDS Virtual Element Test'
@analytics.dataCategory: #DIMENSION
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@vdm.viewType: #BASIC
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations:true
@ObjectModel.usageType.serviceQuality: #A
@ObjectModel.usageType.sizeCategory: #S
@ObjectModel.usageType.dataClass: #MASTER
@analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@analytics.dataExtraction.delta.changeDataCapture.automatic: true
@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities:[#EXTRACTION_DATA_SOURCE]
@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@odata.publish: true

define view entity Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM as select from tka01
{
key kokrs,
substring( cast( tstmp_current_utctimestamp() as abap.char(17) ), 1, 8 ) as dat,
@ObjectModel.readOnly: true
@ObjectModel.virtualElement: true
@ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CALC'
cast('' as abap.sstring( 1 )) as flag
}
where kokrs = '1000'
  •  The annotation at line 13 enables access to the CDS View via the OData Service.
  • The ‘dat’ field is added as a simple log: to see the date of the last calculation run.
  • The ‘flag’ field of the Virtual Element type is defined at line 22. It has the simplest form of a flag field. By default, as can be seen from the code, this field is empty. However, upon completion of calculations on the AS ABAP side, it will be filled with the value 'X'. This flag confirms at DSP side the successful completion of ABAP calculations.
  • The annotations at lines 19-21 define the "flag" field as a Virtual Element. In particular, the @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy annotation specifies the name of the ABAP class that should calculate the ‘flag’ field.

When you initially activate this code, you'll receive, in particular, two warnings. For line 13 the system reports that the corresponding OData service is not active. For line 21 the system reports that the corresponding class doesn't exist. In the next steps, we'll resolve these issues.

If we use the context menu command 'Open With -> Data Preview' on our CDS View at this point, the result will be as follows:Here the 'kokrs' and 'dat' fields are populated using standard CDS syntax. The virtual 'flag' field is left blank.

Creation of ABAP Class implementing our calculations

A Virtual Element calculation implementing  class must use two standard interfaces: IF_SADL_EXIT и IF_SADL_EXIT_CALC_ELEMENT_READ:

class ZCL_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CALC definition
public
final
create public .

public section.

interfaces IF_SADL_EXIT .
interfaces IF_SADL_EXIT_CALC_ELEMENT_READ .
protected section.
private section.
ENDCLASS.

Second of these interfaces has two standard methods. A detailed description of these methods and their parameters can be found in the official documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_BW4HANA/cc0c305d2fab47bd808adcad3ca7ee9d/4b5e56ec6f28453f81a...

In our example, the following code is proposed for the GET_CALCULATION_INFO method:

METHOD if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read~get_calculation_info.
IF iv_entity = 'Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM'.
"Here we'll list which fields of CDS View will be used in virtual element calculation
IF line_exists( it_requested_calc_elements[ table_line = 'FLAG' ] ).
APPEND 'KOKRS' TO et_requested_orig_elements.
ENDIF.
ELSE.
" Potential errors should be processed by public constants,
" described in exceptional class, inherited from CX_SADL_EXIT.
" For example, if CDS View is unknown:

RAISE EXCEPTION TYPE zcx_ds_virt_elem_exceptions EXPORTING textid = zcx_ds_virt_elem_exceptions=>c_entity_not_known.
ENDIF.
ENDMETHOD.

Errors occurring during execution of the class described above must be handled using system messages. For this purpose, public constants will be created in a separate exception class. The class must be a child of the standard CX_SADL_EXIT class. An example of such an exception class is provided in the official documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_NETWEAVER_AS_ABAP_751_IP/cc0c305d2fab47bd808adcad3ca7ee9d/8cf451799476...  

As we can see, after specifying the parent class, a small constructor override is required. Each error is then declared as a public constant attribute. Naturally, such attribute contains a system message, previously defined in the Message Class relevant to the task.

Since our CDS View is designed to be as simple as possible, the IT_REQUESTED_CALC_ELEMENTS table will contain a single row with the ‘FLAG’ field. The ET_REQUESTED_ORIG_ELEMENTS table of regular source fields also contains only one record with the ‘KOKRS’ field.

Let's move on to the CALCULATE method:

METHOD if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read~calculate.
CHECK NOT it_original_data IS INITIAL.
DATA lit_calculated_data TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF z_cds_virt_elem WITH DEFAULT KEY.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING it_original_data TO lit_calculated_data.

LOOP AT lit_calculated_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_calculated_data>).
"Here we need to add a call to the code that we wanted to initiate from the DSP side.
"For example, we can submit some program:
" SUBMIT z_some_program AND RETURN.
<lfs_calculated_data>-flag = 'X'. "Formal flag of the calculation readiness
EXIT. "Additional guarantee that calculation will be performed only once
ENDLOOP.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING lit_calculated_data TO ct_calculated_data.
ENDMETHOD.

Our CDS View is intentionally designed to return exactly one record. This means that in the CALCULATE method, the IT_ORIGINAL_DATA table also contains exactly one record. Consequently, the LOOP/ENDLOOP loop will only be executed once, and the target code will also be called only once.

After the ZCL_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CALC class is activated, the warning on line 21 of our CDS View code will disappear.

OData Service activation

Our CDS View annotation specifies that it can be accessed via an OData Service. When we activate the CDS code, the corresponding OData Service will be created but not activated. Activation must be performed manually in the /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE transaction. The OData Service name consists of the name of our CDS View followed by the _CDS suffix. In our example, the resulting name is Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS.

Click the 'Add Service' button:

 An ‘Add Selected Services’ window will appear. Enter Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS as the technical name, and select LOCAL from the list in the 'System Alias' field. Then click 'Get Services'. A line with our service should appear:

 Select the row with service description and press the ‘Add Selected Services’ button:In the 'Package Assignment' field, specify the appropriate package for subsequent import of developed objects to the production system. In the 'ICF Node' section, select the 'SAP Gateway OData V2' setting. An important setting is the 'Enable OAuth for Service' checkbox. Check with your BASIS Team to determine whether OAuth will be used when connecting the DSP to the ABAP system. If so, enable this checkbox. After confirming the settings, service activation will begin. Upon completion, the following message will appear: 

Now you need to return to the main transaction window and filter the newly activated service in the list:

 Check the traffic light in the 'Status' field (the leftmost field in the ICF Nodes section). If it's yellow, select the drop-down list from the 'ICF Node' button directly above it and execute the 'Activate' command:

The window for selecting a package for importing activated objects into production will appear again:

After this, the traffic light will change to green. You can now test the service by clicking the 'SAP Gateway Client' button:

 By default, the test transaction specifies a URI that reads the service description:

But we're interested in what entities this service can provide. This can be found by clicking the 'Entity Set' button:

Here we see that the service can read data for CDS View Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM. By double-clicking this name, we can change the URI:

If you now click the 'Execute' button, data will be read from the CDS View Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM via the OData Service. This is precisely the operation that should trigger the calculation of the 'flag' field via the ABAP class described above. If you need to study or debug this class, you can set breakpoints there before clicking 'Execute'. The calculation results will be presented here in XML format:Here you can see that the 'flag' field is filled with the value 'X'. This means that the CALCULATE method was executed along with the target code call.

System user authorizations

When creating a DSP connection to an ABAP system, a special user of the System type is used. Typically, the BASIS Team assigns this user a standard set of permissions sufficient for connections of SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP ABAP, or SAP BW types. Experience has shown that a Generic OData connection requires a number of additional permissions.

First, you need to add authorizations to launch the created OData Service. This is the S_SERVICE authorization object. Editing it differs from most standard authorization objects. After adding the object to the role profile, click the edit button for the SRV_NAME field. In the window that appears, select 'TADIR Service' from the Type drop-down list, which will display a list of services allowed to launch:

We need to add two types of objects for our service: IWSG and IWSV. First, select the appropriate type from the list in the 'Object Type' column. Then, use the search (for example, by pressing F4) in the 'Object Name' column. In both cases, you can use the name of our service (i.e. -  Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS) to search for the desired value:The name of the object being searched consists of the service name and the ordinal number of the active version of this service (four digits). For the first version of service in our example, the IWSG type value is 'Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS_0001', and the IWSV type value is 'Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS 0001'.

After saving the selected values, you will see that the value 'HT' is automatically added to the SRV_TYPE field. Thus, the S_SERVICE authorizations have been added and the values ​​specified.

It is also important to note that specific authorizations may be required, which depend on the specific target code you want to run in the CALCULATE method described above. For example, if you plan to use a command like 'SUBMIT z_some_program AND RETURN' to launch a program, you will need the corresponding authorizations in the S_PROGRAM object. If the target code performs, for example, calculations related to the FI module, the system user may require authorizations specific to that module. If the target code accesses the contents of database tables, authorizations in the S_TABU_DIS and S_TABU_NAM objects may be required. And so on. Most likely, during the OData service testing phase (as described in the previous section), you will need to collaborate with the BASIS Team to monitor missing authorizations and add them to the system user's roles. The simplest solution is to temporarily (and only in the development system!) change the user type from system to dialog. In this case, you can log in to the SAP GUI with this user's login and manually run OData service testing while simultaneously monitoring the authorizations being checked.

The security issue of assigning such non-typical authorizations to a system user is mitigated by the fact that this user is created only to connect DSP to the ABAP system and cannot be used for manual data access, like a dialog user.

DSP OData Connection

Creating a Generic OData connection should be performed by BASIS Team specialists, as the required settings depend on the system landscape used in your specific project, as well as the security settings applied (for example, whether OAuth is enabled). Here's an example of the settings used in our project:The address entered in the ‘URL’ field ends with the technical name of our OData service. Therefore, a separate connection will need to be created for each OData service.

In the ‘Version’ field, V2 is selected. This is because we specified OData V2 when activating the service above and didn't have the option to select V4:

The example also shows that OAuth is used. That's why the corresponding checkbox was enabled earlier when activating the service:

At the bottom of the connection settings window, click the ‘Show Advanced Properties’ button:

Here you need to specify for the OData service the client number of the ABAP system we are connecting to:

 

DSP Data Flow to use OData connection and trigger the target code

We need to create a Data Flow with our OData service as a source. To do this, open Data Builder (in the same Space where you created OData service connection). In the left pane, select the 'Sources' tab and open the 'Connections' folder:

If all connection settings and system user authorizations were configured correctly, you will see the connection, and when you expand it, you will see the name of our CDS View:

The icon next to the CDS View is the same as for a regular table. You can drag and drop this View into the Data Flow being created. It will be automatically recognized as a Source. At this step, you can select the 'Preview Data' command for this table:

The result should look like this:

The presence of an 'X' in the 'flag' field means that the target code has been executed on the ABAP system side. If the target code execution takes a long time, you will also notice the delay when viewing it in the DSP.

As a final step, you need to complete the Data Flow by adding the target table to it, which in this case only serves as a dummy. Save the Data Flow and deploy it.

Result

Now you can initiate execution of the target code in the ABAP system in any way convenient for you: by manually starting the Data Flow, scheduling it, or including the Data Flow in a Task Chain.

 

 

Note: Data Preview is not working for Virtual Element

As a result of our implementation, OData Service is activated and implementing ABAP class exist for our Virtual Element. And  we can repeat attempt of CDS data preview in ABAP Development Tools (CDS editor context menu command 'Open With -> Data Preview'). Unfortunately, result will be the same: field ‘flag’ is empty: 

This is explained by the fact that the Virtual Element calculation is performed only when accessing the CDS through OData Service.

Hello,

If you want heading tables on every page why don't you put it on master page? if you put it on master page it will appear every page then.

entry.title: SAP ALM Summit Japan 2025 開催報告
entry.content:
SAP ALM Summit Japan 2025が昨年末12/8（月）、12/9（火）の二日間に渡り、SAPジャパン大手町オフィス11階で開催されました。

この SAP ALM SummitはSAP が提供するグローバルイベントの一つであり、EMEA、North America、Asia Pacific 地域と並び、日本においても毎年年末に開催しております。大変ありがたいことに参加者の数も毎年徐々に増えてきており、今回も延べ約100社のお客様、パートナー様にご参加いただきました。この場を借りて、改めてお礼申し上げます。誠にありがとうございました。

最初のキーノートセッションでは、SAPサポートおよび統合ツールチェーンのグローバル総責任者から最新情報を交えた SAPのALM戦略、またALM Go-to-Market責任者から統合ツールチェーンにおけるSAP Cloud ALMの現在の位置付け、今後リリース予定のAIを活用した機能などについてデモを通じご紹介させていただきました。

キーノートセッションに続く各機能の個別セッションでは、SAP Cloud ALMの導入／運用機能のご紹介だけではなく、SAP Solution Managerからの移行、統合ツールチェーンの各ツールにおけるAI活用の実情、またBusiness Transformation Centerやセキュリティ分析といった比較的新しいトピックもアジェンダに組み込み、各領域のエキスパートからご説明させていただきました。

また、今回日本電気様にご登壇いただき、現在進めておられる統合ツールチェーンの取り組みについてご説明いただいたことが特筆すべき点として挙げられます。実際のご経験から得られる大変貴重な情報ということもあり、セッション当日はご参加いただいた方々から時間ギリギリまで数多くのご質問が出ておりました。

こちらが今回提供した各セッションの資料へのリンクです。

【1日目】

  • セッション1：Keynote 1 – 革新的な業務改革実現の手段と、それを実現するSAP戦略
  • セッション2：Keynote 2 – 革新的な業務改革実現の手段と、それを実現するSAP戦略
  • セッション3：SAP Solution Managerユーザーを後押し！SAP Cloud ALMへの移行に向けた押さえるべきポイント
  • セッション4：AIを用いた統合ツールチェーンによる革新的なプロジェクト管理

【2日目】

  • セッション1：SAP Cloud ALMが実現するセントラルオブザーバビリティおよびシステム運用効率化について
  • セッション2：SAP Cloud ALMを使ったセキュリティ分析で何ができるのか
  • セッション3：SAPが提供する新たな選択肢データ移行向けソリューションBusiness Transformation Center：SAP Cloud ALM
  • セッション4：SAP Cloud ALMとTricentisで実現するテスト効率化の現状と将来像

なお、各セッションのレコーディングをSAPジャパン公式のYoutubeチャンネル（www.youtube.com/@SAPJAPAN）にて今後配信する予定です。こちらについては、もう暫くお待ちください。

また、SAP ALM Summit Japan 2024に引き続き、今回もSolution Transformation Consultant trainingを開催いたしました。

こちらは、RISE with SAP Methodology および clean Core をベースとした S/4HANA 導入プロジェクトおよび本稼働後の運用効率化を図るための各種機能の理解と利用方法を習得できるトレーニングです。このプログラムには理解度を測る認定試験も用意されており、試験にパスするとCredly社経由で認定バッチが提供されます。

今回は、ALM Summit 1日目、2日目の個別セッション終了後に、ハンズオンを交えたワークショップ（1日目：導入編／2日目：運用編）を提供させていただき、その上で認定試験に臨んでいただきました。

こちらもスケジュールが非常にタイトである中、多くのお客様、パートナー様にご参加いただきました。誠にありがとうございました。

以上、簡単ではございますがSAP ALM Summit Japan 2025の開催報告となります。
2026年のALM Summitですが、North America、Asia Pacific、EMEA各地域での開催スケジュールが早くも決定しております（こちらをご参照ください）。

日本での開催については、詳細が決まりましたら今後追ってご連絡させていただく予定です。

最後までお読みいただき、ありがとうございました。

entry.title: SAP ALM Summit Japan 2025 event report
entry.content:
SAP ALM Summit Japan 2025 was held over two days, December 8 (Mon) and December 9 (Tue) last year, on the 11th floor of the SAP Japan Otemachi office.

This SAP ALM Summit is one of SAP’s global events, held annually in regions such as EMEA, North America, and Asia Pacific, and likewise in Japan toward the end of each year. We are very grateful that the number of participants has steadily increased every year, this time, approximately 100 customers and partners joined us over the two days. We would like to take this opportunity to express our sincere appreciation. Thank you very much.



In the opening keynote session, SAP’s Global Head of Support and Integrated Tool Chain shared the latest updates on SAP’s ALM strategy. Additionally, the Go‑to‑Market Lead for ALM introduced the current positioning of SAP Cloud ALM within the integrated tool chain and demonstrated AI‑powered features planned for future releases.
 

In the individual sessions that followed the keynote, experts from each area presented not only SAP Cloud ALM’s implementation and operations capabilities, but also topics such as migration from SAP Solution Manager, practical examples of AI utilization across tools in the integrated toolchain, Business Transformation Center, and security analytics—relatively new themes that were newly added to this year’s agenda.

Another highlight was the session delivered by NEC Corporation, in which they shared their ongoing initiatives related to the integrated toolchain. Since their session was based on real‑world project experience, participants actively asked numerous questions until the very last minute.

Below are the links to the materials provided for each session:

Day1

  • Session 1：Keynote 1 – Means for Achieving Innovative Business Transformation and SAP’s Strategy to Realize It
  • Session 2：Keynote 2 – Means for Achieving Innovative Business Transformation and SAP’s Strategy to Realize It
  • Session 3：Supporting SAP Solution Manager Users! Key Points for Migrating to SAP Cloud ALM
  • Session 4：Innovative Project Management Enabled by an AI‑Driven Integrated Toolchain

Day2

  • Session 1：Central Observability and Operational Efficiency Enabled by SAP Cloud ALM
  • Session 2：What Is Possible with Security Analytics Using SAP Cloud ALM
  • Session 3：Business Transformation Center for SAP Cloud ALM: A New SAP‑Provided Data Migration Solution
  • Session 4：Current State and Future Outlook of Test Optimization Using SAP Cloud ALM and Tricentis
The session recordings will be made available on the official SAP Japan YouTube channel (www.youtube.com/@SAPJAPAN) at a later date. Please stay tuned.
 
Following the SAP ALM Summit Japan 2024, we also held the Solution Transformation Consultant Training this year.
 

This training is designed to help participants understand and learn how to use various functions that support S/4HANA implementation projects and post‑go‑live operational optimization, based on the RISE with SAP Methodology and the clean core concept. A certification exam is provided to assess understanding, and those who pass receive a digital badge issued via Credly.

This time, hands‑on workshops were conducted after the individual sessions on both Day 1 (Implementation track) and Day 2 (Operations track), followed by the certification exam.
Despite the very tight schedule, many customers and partners joined the program. We sincerely appreciate your participation.

This concludes our brief report on SAP ALM Summit Japan 2025.
The schedules for the 2026 ALM Summits in North America, Asia Pacific, and EMEA have already been announced (see details here).

As for the event in Japan, we will inform you once further details are finalized.

Thank you very much for reading.

entry.title: Re: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to change field status of Purchase Requisition

entry.title: Error cannot post to asset in company code XXXX fiscal year 2026
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am facing an issue in Asset Accounting (FI-AA) and would appreciate your guidance.

System behavior

When trying to post a Goods Receipt for Asset (MIGO – movement 101) in fiscal year 2026, the system shows the following error:

AA347 – You cannot post to asset in company code MNSA fiscal year 2026
A year-end carryforward has not yet been performed in Asset Accounting for company code MNSA.

What has already been done

1. Depreciation Posting (AFAB)

- Fiscal year 2025

- No errors (green status)

2. Asset Year-End Closing (AJAB)

- Fiscal year change from 2025 → 2026

- No errors reported

3. Balance Carryforward – General Ledger (FAGLGVTR / SAPFGLBCF)

- Executed for company code MNSA, ledger 0L

- However, during the run, I still get multiple messages like:

“Balance carryforward for account 131xxxxx in ledger 0L is not correct”
(mostly asset reconciliation accounts)

4. Posting periods for 2026 are open.

Questions:

1. Is AJAB sufficient for asset year-end carryforward in S/4HANA, or is there any other program replacing AJRW?

2. Should FAGLGVTR errors on asset reconciliation accounts prevent posting in FI-AA, even if AJAB and AFAB are successful?

3. What is the correct sequence to fully unlock asset postings in the new fiscal year?

 

Thank you in advance for your help and insights.

Best regards,
Ester Wang

entry.title: Unlocking Reliability at Scale: Join Our Webinar on Asset Performance Management and Industry X
entry.content:
In the ever-evolving landscape of asset management, the integration of cutting-edge technology and innovative strategies is crucial for staying ahead. Here at SAP, in collaboration with Accenture, we are thrilled to invite you to a groundbreaking webinar designed to explore how Asset Performance Management (APM) and Industry X are revolutionizing the industry. This session will empower asset owners, plant managers, and reliability engineers to optimize maintenance strategies, enhance asset performance, and achieve sustainability objectives—all while tackling the most significant challenges facing the industry today.

Why Attend? This exclusive webinar provides a unique opportunity to:

- Gain Insight from Industry Leaders: Hear directly from M. Dias Branco about their transformative journey in asset management.
- Engage with Experts: Connect with international specialists from SAP and Accenture, and deepen your understanding of emerging trends and tools.
- Discover Next-Level Innovation: Learn how innovation and AI capabilities are unlocking new avenues of value within APM.
- Shape the Future: Participate in an interactive virtual workshop where your feedback can influence the direction of future advancements.

3. M. Dias Branco Client Story:

4. Reliability-at-Scale Key Innovation for SAP Asset Performance Management:
- Elmar Paul will introduce the latest and planned innovations delivering reliability at scale, providing attendees with actionable strategies to implement in their operations.

5. Q&A Session:
- An open forum to discuss pressing questions and explore further the topics covered during the webinar.

Join us for this engaging session to catalyse your approach to asset management, foster sustainability, and lead in your industry with enhanced reliability and efficiency. Secure your spot in this transformative event and be part of shaping the future of Asset Performance Management.

entry.title: Re: Show last 6 month data using fiscal period
entry.content:
TYPES : BEGIN OF ts_period ,

period TYPE numc3, ind type i,

END OF ts_period.



DATA : periodary TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ts_period.
periodary = VALUE #( ( period = '001' ind = 989 ) ( period = '002' ind = 1 ) ( period = '003' ind = 1 ) ( period = '004' ind = 1 )
( period = '005' ind = 1 ) ( period = '006' ind = 1 ) ( period = '007' ind = 1 ) ( period = '008' ind = 1 )
( period = '009' ind = 1 ) ( period = '010' ind = 1 ) ( period = '011' ind = 1 ) ( period = '012' ind = 1 ) ).

READ TABLE it_filter-TT_Fiscalyearperiod INTO DATA(ls_per) INDEX 1. " first period for example 2026001
DATA(lv_last) = substring( val = ls_per-low off = 4 len = 3 ).
data(ls_period) = periodary[ period = lv_last ] .
DATA(lv_ind) = ls_period-ind .
do 5 times.
ls_per-low = ls_per-low - lv_ind . "substring( val = ls_per-low off = 0 len = 4 ) && periodary[ ind = lv_ind ]-period.
append ls_per to it_filter-TT_Fiscalyearperiod.
lv_last = substring( val = ls_per-low off = 4 len = 3 ).
ls_period = periodary[ period = lv_last ] .
lv_ind = ls_period-ind.

ENDDO.

entry.title: Від ритейлу до енергетики: як український бізнес отримує міжнародне визнання
entry.content:
Українські компанії з різних галузей — енергетики, ритейлу, промисловості та ІТ-консалтингу — здобули перемоги на SAP Quality Awards 2025 у регіоні Центральної та Східної Європи. Проєкти були відзначені за швидкість впровадження новітніх технологій, інноваційність і відчутний бізнес-ефект. Це підтверджує, що український бізнес не лише зберігає операційну стійкість, а й задає стандарти цифрової трансформації на регіональному рівні.

У 2025 році журі SAP Quality Awards відзначило одразу кілька проєктів з України, які продемонстрували різні підходи до трансформації — від cloud-впроваджень і мобільних рішень до HR-та ритейл-інновацій.

Швидкість і cloud-first — Business Evolution

Компанія Business Evolution реалізувала SAP Cloud ERP лише за 4 місяці, використовуючи підхід Fit-to-Standard і стандартний функціонал SAP. Проєкт отримав нагороду Rapid Time to Value.

Результати після запуску:

  • закриття місяця — 4 робочі дні;
  • автоматизація 80% обробки рахунків;
  • зменшення навантаження на фінансову команду до 30%;
  • повна відмова від власної інфраструктури завдяки cloud-моделі.

 Більше інформації за посиланням.

Мобільність і критична інфраструктура — Оператор ГТС України

ТОВ «Оператор ГТС України» отримав нагороду в категорії Business Transformation – Enterprise Solutions, а також спеціальну відзнаку SAP Quality Director Award.

Мобільний застосунок на базі SAP BTP:

  • повністю замінив паперові процеси;
  • працює офлайн;
  • скоротив поїздки між об’єктами та офісами на 40%;
  • зменшив час обробки даних на 40%.

Рішення вже використовують понад 350 фахівців, і проєкт масштабують далі.

Більше інформації за посиланням.

HR як стратегічний інструмент — Метінвест

Група Метінвест була відзначена за трансформацію HR-процесів через масштабування SAP SuccessFactors на підприємстві «Каметсталь». Проєкт здобув перемогу в категорії Business Transformation – Functional Transformation.

Ключові ефекти:

  • у 5 разів скорочено час оцінювання;
  • у 2,5 раза зменшено витрати на ручну обробку;
  • усунено суб’єктивізм в оцінці персоналу;
  • сформовано культуру регулярного зворотного зв’язку.

Більше інформації за посиланням.

Масштаб у ритейлі — NOVUS

Один із найбільших ритейлерів країни — NOVUS — впровадив SAP Merchandising and Inventory Management у 96 магазинах по всій Україні та здобув перемогу в категорії «Business Transformation – Enterprise Solutions»

Результати:

  • робота з даними в режимі реального часу;
  • удвічі швидша генерація замовлень;
  • зменшення втрат продажів через порожні полиці;
  • відмова від додаткових систем і зниження ІТ-витрат.

 Більше інформації за посиланням.

«Перемоги українських компаній на SAP Quality Awards 2025 демонструють, що навіть у складних умовах бізнес в Україні інвестує в ефективність, інновації та довгостроковий розвиток. Ці проєкти стали прикладом того, як технології допомагають не лише оптимізувати процеси, а й підтримувати економічну стабільність країни». — зазначила Ганна Мікулицька, керівна директорка SAP Ukraine.

SAP Quality Awards — це щорічна міжнародна винагорода, яка відзначає найкращі проєкти впровадження SAP за інноваційність, дотримання принципів якості та вимірювану бізнес-цінність. Цього року премія SAP Quality Awards була представлена у трьох основних категоріях: «Business Transformation – Enterprise Solutions», «Business Transformation – Functional Transformation» та «Rapid Time to Value».

Довідка про компанію

У 2025 році компанія відзначала 30 років діяльності на українському ринку. Сьогодні близько 200 українських організацій, зокрема державні установи, а також підприємства нафтогазового, енергетичного, металургійного, фармацевтичного секторів, сфери торгівлі та професійних послуг, використовують рішення SAP. В Україні існує мережа висококваліфікованих партнерів SAP, які надають свої послуги. Компанія активно допомагає українському бізнесу та благодійним фондам, які підтримують постраждалих від війни громадян. Детальніше про розвиток SAP в Україні — на сторінці, присвяченій ювілею компанії. Ознайомитися можна за посиланням. Більше детальної інформації про компанію SAP та її рішення можна отримати на сайті: www.sap.ua.

entry.title: Re: Problem with requirement types in strategy group 30
entry.content:
No, you cannot register planned independent requirements (PIRs) with strategy group 30 in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition because the requirement type is blank. Unlike ECC, where strategy group 30 was linked to requirement type LSF, the Cloud edition does not provide this assignment by default. To enable PIRs, you must use a different planning strategy group (such as 40 or 10) or configure requirement type assignments in the configuration environment.

So what you can do is reassign your material master from strategy group 30 to 40 (VSF) if you need PIRs with sales order consumption, or to 10 (PD) if you only need pure make-to-stock PIRs. This will resolve the error and allow PIR registration.

entry.title: 10 reasons to trust the SAP Business Transformation Center with your data migration
entry.content:
We get it. When SAP launches something new, the skepticism is real. "Another product that experiments on customers?" "Will this actually work in production?" "Does SAP really understand what we're dealing with on the ground?" These are fair questions, especially when you're responsible for migrating mission-critical ERP systems.

SAP Business Transformation Center (SAP BTC) is the new kid on the block for data migration, but it's far from immature. Here's what sets it apart and why you can trust it with your most important projects.

 

1. Built by People Who've Been in the Trenches

SAP BTC wasn't dreamed up in an ivory tower. The product owners have decades of hands-on experience in data transformation projects. They've seen what works, what fails, and what keeps consultants up at night. That expertise is baked into every feature and workflow.

 

2. Built on Proven Methodologies, Not Experiments

SAP BTC leverages battle-tested data migration approaches that have been refined over many years. Take Selective Data Transition (SDT) as one example—it's been used successfully in thousands of projects by tens of thousands of customers for more than two decades. SAP BTC builds on these, giving you the confidence that comes with proven strategies.

 

3. No More Dependency on Scarce Expertise

One of the biggest bottlenecks in data migration projects? Finding consultants with the right knowledge. SAP BTC provides intelligent guidance based on actual data analyzed in your source system. You can get started quickly without waiting months for specialized expertise to become available.

 

4. End-to-End Coverage

SAP BTC handles the entire migration journey, from analyzing your source system to validating data in the target. You're not stitching together multiple tools and hoping they play nicely. Everything you need is in one place, reducing complexity and integration risks.

 

5. Modern User Experience That Doesn't Feel Like Legacy SAP

SAP BTC offers a genuinely modern, intuitive user experience based on Fiori Elements. Your team won't need extensive training just to navigate the interface or understand what's happening.

 

6. Smart Orchestration with Proven Technology

SAP BTC combines cloud capabilities with the reliability of the ABAP execution engine, the same technology powering the SAP Landscape Transformation Replication Server (SLT). This isn't experimental tech. It's perfectly suited for table-oriented data migration and has been proven in countless enterprise deployments.

 

7. Pre-Built Content from Years of Real-World Projects

SAP Services has been refining migration content and methodological knowledge across almost all industries, regions, and customer groups for years—not in a lab, but in real customer environments facing real challenges. SAP BTC packages this hard-won knowledge into predefined content you can use immediately. You're not starting from scratch; you're building on collective wisdom earned in the field.

 

8. Data Footprint Reduction Made Easy

Migrating to SAP S/4HANA is the perfect time to clean house. SAP BTC makes it straightforward to reduce your data footprint by identifying what's truly needed and what can be discarded. Less data means faster migrations, lower costs, and better performance in your new system.

 

9. Fact-Based Decision Making

No more guessing or relying on gut feelings. SAP BTC provides data-driven insights that let you make informed decisions throughout the project. You can scope accurately, plan realistically, and set stakeholder expectations based on actual system analysis, not assumptions.

 

10. Test with Confidence, Deploy with Certainty

SAP BTC's versioning concept allows for rapid test cycles. More importantly, a configuration that works in testing can be used exactly as-is for go-live. And here's a crucial point: migration happens between your source and target systems. No sensitive data enters the cloud, addressing a major security concern many organizations have.

 

Ready to Look Under the Hood?

SAP Business Transformation Center represents a new generation of migration tooling, but it's built on decades of proven methodology and expertise. If you're planning a move to S/4HANA and want to explore how SAP BTC can make your journey smoother, check out our SAP Help Portal or visit the official SAP BTC page in the SAP Support Portal for detailed documentation and resources. 

The data migration challenge hasn't gotten easier, but the tools finally have.

entry.title: Re: Adobe forms: Header paragraph need to repeat every page
entry.content:
Hi,
Like @hamzaefe stated the best practice is to put static content in the master pages so that it gets repeated on each page.

Then shrink the size of the main section (in my screenshot the 'Items' section) so that it starts below the header

There is alternatives, but these can be tricky to get working.
Putting a page header in the master page as a static subform is the best way 😉

Kr,
Joery

entry.title: How AI Transforms Customer Experience (CX) in SAP Product Lines of Business
entry.content:
Introduction:

Customer experience (CX) has become the cornerstone of business success. In today’s digital economy, customers expect fast, personalized, and seamless interactions. Artificial Intelligence (AI) is revolutionizing how organizations deliver these experiences, and SAP’s Product Lines of Business (LoB) are leveraging AI to make this transformation possible.

1. Why AI Matters for Customer Service CX

  • Personalization at Scale: AI enables businesses to understand customer behavior and preferences, delivering tailored recommendations and solutions.
  • 24/7 Availability: AI-powered chatbots and virtual assistants ensure customers receive support anytime, anywhere.
  • Predictive Insights: AI can anticipate customer needs, reducing friction and improving satisfaction.
  • Efficiency and Cost Reduction: Automating repetitive tasks frees up human agents for complex issues, improving productivity.

2. AI Use Cases in Customer Service

  • Intelligent Chatbots: Handle FAQs, troubleshoot issues, and escalate complex cases.
  • Sentiment Analysis: Understand customer emotions in real-time to adapt responses.
  • Predictive Service: AI predicts potential issues before they occur, enabling proactive support.
  • Voice and Conversational AI: Enhance call center interactions with natural language processing.

3. How SAP LoB Integrates AI for CX

SAP’s LoBs (e.g., SAP Customer Experience, SAP Service Cloud, SAP Commerce Cloud) embed AI capabilities to deliver superior CX:

  • SAP Service Cloud: AI-driven ticket routing and automated case resolution.
  • SAP Commerce Cloud: Personalized product recommendations using machine learning.
  • SAP Sales Cloud: Intelligent lead scoring and next-best-action suggestions.
  • SAP Business AI: Embedded AI services across SAP applications for predictive analytics and automation.

4. Business Impact of AI in SAP CX

  • Improved Customer Satisfaction: Faster resolution and personalized engagement.
  • Operational Efficiency: Reduced handling time and optimized resource allocation.
  • Revenue Growth: Better upselling and cross-selling through AI-driven insights.
  • Scalability: AI enables businesses to handle growing customer demands without proportional cost increases.

5. Future Outlook

AI will continue to evolve with generative AI, conversational intelligence, and hyper-personalization. SAP’s commitment to embedding AI into its LoBs ensures businesses stay ahead in delivering exceptional CX.

Conclusion:

AI is not just a technology trend—it’s a strategic enabler for customer-centric organizations. By integrating AI into SAP’s Product LoBs, businesses can transform customer service into a competitive advantage.

entry.title: Re: Missing Legally Required Company Address Fields for E...
entry.content:
Hello @nbek 

Thank you for your question

Answer to question 1:

Generally, you do not need the Location API to retrieve the seller’s address. This is because the source for the company code address is through the company’s Code API. The public cloud includes AddressID and other legal attributes. I therefore suggest you use the AddressID to read the actual address from Business Address Services. See https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/c3da95a01a7d44118786bb83b55c464c.html  for more details.

You can get the official company code addresses that is maintained in S4 by:

  • Calling API_COMPANYCODE_SRV to issue you CompanyCode and then read AddressID through it.
  • Calling a released address by using that AddressID to enable you get details like street, house number Postcode, etc.

Alternatively, a supported pattern is also a legal entity that is maintained as a BP. If you use the legal entity as a BP that is mapped to the Compan Code, you have the possibility to retrieve the address with API_BUSINESS_PARTNER. See Assign Business Partners to Company Codes and Business Partner (A2X) – OData API for more insights.

Answer to question 2 on the recommended approach:

Generally, it is recommended to used released APIs (A2X) for your master data and any document payload you want to enrich, for example Company Code and Address services, BP where you deem necessary.

 

Regarding Belgian e-invocing in public cloud, these Blogs provides some valuable insights:

Understanding the Belgium B2B e-Invoicing Mandate and the Plant Abroad Scenario

Electronic Invoicing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Material availability date is considering the Avg Ins...
entry.content:
• GRPT: Time needed by the warehouse team to move material from GR to stock.
  • AID: Time needed for quality inspection before the material is released to unrestricted stock.
  • System logic: When both are maintained, the system takes the longer of the two as the controlling factor for MAD.
    • If AID > GRPT → Inspection time dominates.
    • If GRPT > AID → Warehouse processing dominates.

That’s why in your first case (GRPT=2, AID=3), MAD is pushed out by 3 days (inspection). In the second case (GRPT=3, AID=2), MAD is pushed out by 3 days (warehouse).

Yes, this can delay production if inspection takes longer than warehouse processing, because the material is not available until inspection is complete. The system is designed this way to ensure that only usable stock is considered available.

In short, the system always prioritizes whichever duration is longer (GRPT vs. AID). If you want warehouse time to be considered, set GRPT higher than AID. If inspection dominates, AID will control MAD. Businesses usually model whichever is the true bottleneck.

entry.title: More Effective Security Programs Through Security Risk Quantification
entry.content:
By Josh Marker, Head of Security Risk Management,  and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

 

Security Risks, Enterprise Risks, and Business Priorities

This year has seen a further rise in cyber threats with increasing business impact. Just in recent months, cyber attacks have disrupted retail chains, air travel and beer production, and an entire supply chain in the automotive industry requiring government support. Managing security risks well is more critical than ever to organizations.

From our conversations with customers and partners, we know that business leaders are concerned about security and compliance risks. We also know that many security leaders still struggle to communicate security risks, and, given the current climate, face challenges to justify investment when organizations are looking to cut cost and run more efficiently. Both sides are familiar and comfortable with uncertainty and balancing their respective risks. Business leaders set out strategic directions they bet the success of the company on, by opening new markets, launching new product lines, or investing in new technologies where despite good execution external factors outside of their control may determine the outcome. Security leaders similarly chart out strategies and uplift programs they anticipate will best defend their organizations against unpredictable and ever evolving threats. The remaining challenge to action appears to be miscommunication and misalignment.

For effective communication and decision on the appropriate response, we need to translate security risks into business terms, and in ways that they can be related and prioritized alongside enterprise risks and business priorities. At SAP, we have found that a quantitative security risk approach, based on the methodology of the FAIR Institute, is very helpful in providing that, as well as hold the organization to account driving change and effective progress through measurable accountability.

 

Risk Identification, Analysis and Response

Every risk analysis involves some combination of probability x impact. The problem is that calculating either is very difficult. There is in cybersecurity in general a lack of good data, but organizations struggle even more to estimate to probability of a particular event to occur in their own landscape – especially if a new threat hasn’t happened yet. Impact is similarly difficult to estimate, as that depends in large part on the intent and actions of the adversary. This forces you to shoehorn more likely but lower impact events together with low probability but catastrophic potential outcomes.

The common “rainbow” risk matrix is a poor communicator for this. Even when category ranges are appropriately chosen, and position of the risk on the matrix is justified, it gives an inappropriately definite and reductive answer that allows risks to both be under- and overrated. It doesn’t tell the whole story and therefore is often not a useful communication device to convince others – especially those outside cybersecurity and business leaders - investment or action is required.

Risk Identification and Analysis with a Quantitative Approach

To better express this larger story, we need an approach that expresses risk in financial terms. It also needs to allow for uncertainty in the world. And it should account for inputs that are sometimes educated guesses.

In SAP, during risk identification, we try to capture as many parameters as possible for which we can reasonably find information or can make informed guesses on based on threat intelligence data and landscape scans of the likelihood the threat materializes in a given year. Subject matter experts (SMEs) provide the information, when can be expressed in a range – avoiding the conversation falling in “it depends” traps.

“Defenders have to be right all the time, attackers only once”, is a common theme in cybersecurity. The reality is that attackers usually require multiple steps to succeed before they reach any data and system with high business impact, giving defenders multiple opportunities to put obstacles in their way, or detect and contain them. Attackers can be extremely lucky, by obtaining credentials of exactly the right privileged administrator, but more likely they follow a longer path of initial access, persistence, privilege escalation and lateral movement. By allowing the domain experts to express a range of scenarios and consequences for these parameters, supported by data available, we get a far more nuanced understanding of the risk.

Core input for impact is based on direct financial loss in case the risk materializes, to keep the financial calculation conservative and avoid exaggerating a risk. It’s always easier to present your case when able to say other less tangible downstream consequences are not included in the analysis, and the impact could be higher.

To make sense of the data ranges in the parameters, we use machine learning and run 50,000 Monte Carlo simulations to create a model for the risk scenario. This results in a dataset that is sorted by probability and impact and plotted on a graph. A curve is drawn through the data points, resulting in the Loss Exceedance Curve. This curve and the analysis that led to that is reviewed with the SMEs to validate if they agree and accept the results.

By following the curve from the top left to the bottom right, we can see what loss we can expect with what probability. In this example, the curve starts with a steep slope, indicating that a certain percentage of cases where the risk is manifested the impact is low. After that, the curve flattens out and ends with a long tail indicating rare but catastrophic cases. The way to read this is to find a probability along the vertical axis, for example 5%, then trace a horizontal line from that value until it intersects with the Loss Exceedance Curve. Follow a vertical line down from that intersection point to find the value along the horizontal axis, so in this case there is a 5% chance to exceed $126.4M in loss (in any given year, from this scenario). An average and 90th percentile financial impact is provided as an easy to remember label used in conversations, but always with the understanding of the curve behind it.

By updating the values of model parameters, we can express how planned remediations effect the financial risk by running the same Monte Carlo simulations to produce a Loss Exceedance Curve for the risk after remediations. That provides a projection of risk reduction for any investment or effort required. The model for the risk can also be rerun when new information emerges – internally or externally – that requires updating the parameters.

 

Loss Exceedance Curve as Communication Device

The Loss Exceedance Curve is very useful for security leaders to better understand their organization’s security risks, and how proposed remediations reduce that risk and what risk remains after any mitigations have been deployed and operationalized. This can be a sobering exercise if the investment to remediate is too close to the risk and projected risk reduction, forcing you to reevaluate your approach. On the other hand, it can also provide strong justification for that investment if it is only a fraction of the risk and risk reduction that would deliver.

But it works also well with business- and executive leaders. The narrative can be entirely expressed in likelihood and impact in financial terms, while avoiding complexity. The conversation takes place without cyber security jargon, aside from terms business leaders are bound to be familiar with from business reports, such as ransomware attacks and social engineering. It allows business leaders to evaluate security risks better and decide what scenarios they want to protect against and whether they consider the needed effort or investment justified. At times, even a small probability of a catastrophic outcome can lead to a business decision to address a low average risk threat. In other cases, the same business leaders can be more comfortable to accept a reasonable residual risk at a higher probability. Meanwhile, there is no need to go into technical details and explain how such threats would materialize that could derail the discussion, unless a business leader specifically requests it.

When business leaders challenge the impact parameters, the model can be adjusted with more accurate information and the simulations rerun. Since business leaders typically own risks – security or enterprise – it is just as important that they stand behind the inputs into the model as the security and compliance SMEs. The balance between risk reduction and remediation cost along the curve further helps justification for investment of financial and human resources. If most of the risk can be addressed with a minor investment, this can set the upper limit of what is feasible. On the other hand, the long tail of the curve can justify a greater investment to limit the likelihood and impact of catastrophic events.

Allowing both sides to debate the risk through the Loss Exceedance Curve and follow its slope, it serves as an excellent communication device. It helps security and business leaders to get on the same page and express complex scenarios in a way both can understand and relate to.

 

Investment Prioritization and Optimization

The quantification of security risks enables prioritization among them and see where there may be overlaps in mitigation strategies. The remediation plan for one risk is likely to have positive impact on other risks in a layered defense approach. For instance, stronger automated network controls are likely to have a positive impact on the reachability of known vulnerabilities, beyond their immediate intent to protect the network. Such remediations should be prioritized.

Other risks can prove not to have much business impact at all in relation to others. Security professionals and business leaders are prone to overreaction when certain threats hit the media – whether through security conferences or business press – and overvalue the importance of a threat. Risk quantification assists in prioritizing what is important and avoids chasing ghosts while greater immediate risks remain. This way, constrained budgets can be optimized for greater effectiveness in risk reduction.

 

Security Program Governance

The effects are even greater when the risk analysis and response tracking are tied to data than indicates progress along the remediation plan. For instance, the percentage compliance of the landscape with security policies, or how well a team meets remediation target timelines for alerts from landscape scans, or how fast a team adopts a central service can be directly tied to model parameters. That way the model can be rerun with updated parameters as remediation plans progress to show how much risk has been reduced for the effort and how well the organization is progressing on the planned timeline.

The Loss Exceedance Curve aids in target setting, as well. It protects us against unrealistic expectations of targets that can’t be achieved or require high effort to squeeze out a bit more risk reduction. At the same time, it prevents organizations from setting targets too low, because it believes that is what the available resources can achieve. The Loss Exceedance Curve shows at what percentage of remediation of the threat the residual risk falls to an acceptable level. That level is the target to achieve.

 

Summary

The Loss Exceedance Curve helps express the uncertainty that we find in the world: ranges of values are used for inputs which means that variations in outputs need to be expressed. The Loss Exceedance Curve helps us do that, enabling better conversations among various stakeholders, including SMEs who live and breathe the cyber jargon, as well as the managers and business leaders who make decisions that govern and guide the organization.

This approach leads to truly risk-informed decisions and prioritization, rather than what feels good, what cyber textbooks tell us, what vendors sell, or what was exciting at the latest security conference.

 

More Information

For more information, please see:

  • Which UK retailers have been hit by cyber attacks in 2025?
  • EU agency confirms ransomware attack behind airport disruptions
  • Brewer Asahi suspends domestic operations after cyberattack disrupts ordering and shipping
  • Government to guarantee £1.5bn JLR loan after cyber shutdown
  • FAIR Institute

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series : My Terrace Garden
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Sumaiya, and I joined SAP in 2015 as a Scholar and since then have worked in different areas and roles.

Today, I’d love to share a little about my hobby as part of the SAP Community Hobbies series 🌱

What began as a simple interest is now a green space with over 300 plants, including fruit plants, vegetables, ornamental plants, succulents, and cactus. It is my space to slow down, reconnect, and find joy beyond screens and schedules.

Aerial view of my terrace garden

 Once an empty wall, now a layered story of vines, foliage, and flowers growing together.

Succulent Mini garden

 

 

How and when did I start this hobby?

During the COVID period, when we were home most of the time, that old familiarity returned. My husband and I started with just a few plants on our terrace—nothing ambitious. But slowly, one plant became many. Caring for them became part of our daily life, bringing calm, purpose, and continuity in an uncertain time.

Looking back, gardening taught me patience long before I recognized it as a lesson. You cannot rush a seedling or force a fruit to ripen—it grows in its own time, as long as you show up consistently.

Started with Few Palm plants and Jasmine

 

What does my garden look like today?

Our home garden includes fruit plants like pomegranate, chickoo, mango, rose apple, sweet lime, star fruit, mulberry, figs, guava and lemon;

vegetable plants such as curry leaves, Drumstick, chillies, beans, tapioca, sweet potato, coriander;

along with ornamental plants, succulents, and cactus.

We may get just 3–4 mangoes in a season, but the joy has never been about the numbers.

Sapodilla, Figs, Green Pepper (Which post drying in sunlight is used as Black Pepper)

 

French Beans, Mangoes, Pomegranate, Rose Apple and Drumstick (Moringa Plant)

The Bright Colors in the green garden

 

What do I love most about it?

The biggest reward is the experience.

Seeing a plant every day, watching it grow slowly, noticing the first bud, and waiting eagerly for it to ripen—it creates a kind of happiness that’s hard to explain. When your own plant finally bears fruit, it feels like a quiet celebration.

I truly enjoy showing my plants to others. Sharing that space gives me deep, immense happiness and a sense of gratitude for small, everyday wins.

Colorful Blooms that makes the day even brighter

 

Challenges and how I deal with them

Gardening isn’t always easy. Some plants don’t survive. Some seasons don’t cooperate. And because our plants are on an open terrace, weeds have been one of the biggest challenges. Most weekends are spent patiently removing them, making sure they don’t overpower the plants we’ve worked so hard to nurture.

Another persistent challenge is mealy bugs—they require constant attention and effort to control. Since we strongly believe in keeping our garden as natural as possible, we avoid chemical solutions. Instead, we rely on organic remedies, using neem oil and turmeric, which may take more time but align with how we want to care for our plants.

Each challenge has taught me to observe more closely, adapt quickly, and accept that not everything is within my control. Every setback becomes a lesson—for the next plant, the next season.

A proud moment

My proud moments are not big milestones. They are simple, quiet ones:

the first fruit on a plant I nurtured from the beginning,

a plant that survived when I truly thought it wouldn’t,

and a harvest that felt earned, not measured.

One plant I will always remember is a snake plant I gifted myself on my birthday during the lockdown. It arrived in a tiny 3–4 inch pot. As it grew, I repotted it into a larger one, and soon I noticed new plants appearing around it. I separated them into individual pots—and the cycle kept repeating. Today, I have over 30–40 snake plants, and I can no longer tell which one was the very first. Somehow, that makes me smile even more.

Propagating from one single snake plant into so many that covered my walking passage, truly this plant amazes me!

 

As our plants grew, they also became homes for life beyond us. We’ve had bulbul birds visit our terrace frequently, building nests among the plants. Over the past two years, they built nests three times and laid eggs. Watching those eggs hatch and seeing tiny baby birds grow was incredibly heartwarming—it felt like our garden had become a safe space not just for plants, but for living beings too.

BulBul Birds looking for a spot to make a nest

 

 

Bulbul bird nest with 2 eggs hatched

 

More recently, we noticed birds slowly discovering our garden. We began placing bird food, and with time, the number of visitors kept increasing. One evening, we heard the most beautiful chorus of birds and stepped out onto the terrace to witness a magical sight—over 20 Munia birds gathered together, calmly enjoying the space. It was a moment of pure joy and gratitude.

Bird Food we placed thinking Bulbul birds will stay in terrace permanently, but something different happened. Looks like this bird food, Munia bird likes more

 

What makes me most proud is seeing this love for plants extend beyond me. My kids often join us while watering the plants, and my 7-year-old daughter especially looks forward to fruit-harvesting days—those moments turn the garden into shared joy and lasting memories.

These experiences remind me that when you show up consistently and care deeply, growth happens—sometimes quietly, sometimes in ways you never expected.

Tools and resources for beginners  and Tips for getting started

If you are completely new to gardening and worried about plants dying, I always recommend starting simple and stress-free.

A great place to begin is with succulents, especially Mother of Millions. Succulents are incredibly forgiving. You can pluck just one leaf, and it will grow into a new plant. With Mother of Millions, it’s even more fascinating—a single leaf can grow into 10–15 new plants. It requires very little care: moist soil and watering on alternate days, or even once every 2–3 days, works just fine.

Plant : Mother Of Millions

 

Another easy and joyful way to start is by regrowing vegetables in water. Take a small portion of used vegetables, place it in a bottle or container with water, and keep it in indirect sunlight. You’ll be surprised at how quickly new growth appears. A small piece of ginger or sweet potato can grow into a healthy plant with fresh leaves. Even a partly used onion placed in water can turn into fresh spring onions—perfect for a quick salad.

In the Kitchen when i see even a small possibility that the vegetables are sprouting, then instead of cooking them, i put in water bottle to help it grow and then repot in some pot and this cycle repeats

 

Many plants don’t even need soil to begin with. Simply place them in a bottle of water and change the water once a week. It’s minimal effort with maximum joy.

Easiest way to grow plans with minimum effort.

 

You don’t need a big space or expensive tools to start gardening. All it really takes is curiosity, patience, and a little care—and the confidence grows along with the plants 🌱

How I keep improving

Over the years, I’ve learned that not every plant needs the same kind of care. Some grow easily with minimal effort, while others demand time, attention, and patience. Understanding this difference has been one of the most valuable lessons gardening has taught me.

With time, confidence grows—and so does curiosity. I’ve become more comfortable trying new plants and new challenges, learning through experience rather than perfection. Each season adds a little more awareness, a little more patience.

Growth doesn’t always need rigid structure. Sometimes, it simply needs time, consistency, and care.

 

The connection to the SAP world

The connection is stronger than it appears.

Gardening is about systems thinking—understanding dependencies like soil, water, sunlight, and timing. You can’t optimize one part and ignore the rest.

In SAP projects, we build solutions that must be sustainable, balanced, and human-centric. Gardening reminds me that real success comes from nurturing systems patiently, not forcing outcomes.

It helps me show up at work more grounded, focused, and calm.

 

 

What’s next? There’s no finish line here—just more learning, more plants, and more quiet joy. I look forward to continuing this journey, one leaf, one flower, and one fruit at a time.

Thank you for reading. If gardening resonates with you—or if you’re curious about how to start, what to grow, or how to nurture plants at home—I’d be happy to connect and have a chat 🌿

And if you have a hobby that helps you slow down, disconnect, or think better, I’d love to hear about it.

entry.title: Re: VS Code Fiori Generator - Authentication failed: Unable to access any service catalogs
entry.content:
Some of my SAP user password characters were not supported.

Rt¸L¶Ôg%vó÷V)#ÓgÝ3äÜ

I have investigated which ones are supported, and which ones are not:

  • These characters are NOT supported: roman characters with accents and symbols outside US-ASCII like Ôó÷ÓÝäÜ etc.
  • These characters are supported: A to Z, a to z, 0 to 9 and ALL characters which are part of US-ASCII: !"#$%&'()*+,-./:;<=>?@[\]^_`{|}~

For information:

  1. This article says that with S/4HANA ON-PREMISE, SAP Fiori tools running in VS Code support only the authentication type "Basic authentication".
  2. This article says that the HTTP basic authentication supports user names and passwords containing only US-ASCII characters (with reference to the note 1240796 - HTTP logon with Basic Authorization or special character; this note was posted in 2008 and not updated, but maybe it's still valid).
  3. This article and RFC7617 (September 2015) say that the HTTP Basic Authentication can support the transport of user names and passwords via « the charset auth-param » whose « only allowed value is "UTF-8" » i.e. characters not limited to US-ASCII.
  4. I'll open a ticket with SAP Support.

Thanks @amontella96 and @Joery .

entry.title: Re: BADI MMIM_ITEM_PROVIDE_DATA doesn't get triggered dur...
entry.content:
Hello @taufikkasim 

Thank you for your question

The MMIM_ITEM_PROVIDE_DATA is specific for MIGO and GR scenarios. Hence why it does not trigger the desired action in your scenario. So, your custom fields exists in FDP_GR4PO_COL_SLIP_SRV extension but the system does not execute enhancement spot in the SES driven posting step that fills the document, which is why it stays blank. It is a limited pattern for MMIM BAdIs and this is explained in KBA 2956742. You can also read App Extensibility: Post Goods Movement for more details.

On your question about a BAdI you can use for SES scenario, it is important to note that the public cloud extensibility does not generally provide alternative BAdI that lets you populate those Goods Movement slip data source custom fields during the SES approval created material document step.

Considering the public cloud emphasises on keeping the core clean, I suggest you:

  1. Use only fields that are already available and filled in your data source. Basically, saying you should extend the same data source and use the available underlying fields and not create new ones in posting. See KBA 3673885 for more details.
  2. Change your process so that you post GR through a GR app that supports MMIM BAdIs. Basically, saying you should avoid posting automatically through SES. This will allow your current approach with MMIM BAdIs to execute reliably. See KBA 2956742 and App Extensibility: Post Goods Movement for more insights.
  3. If your requirement is purely to enrich printing, consider using output time enrichment where you can. You can use output time for example to fill custom fields when processing your output rather than during document creation. See KBA 3008187 and  https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/47845e7df8f14ecfaf34079d229f031f.html for more details.

To summarise:

  • HU or backend BAdI is not the issue here.
  • The root cause is process context. The GR slip is printed for a material document that is created from SES approval, while your MMIM_ITEM_PROVIDE_DATA BAdI is only executed for supported GR apps, not this background SES posting.
  • Public cloud strongly suggests staying within available fields in FDP_GR4PO_COL_SLIP_SRV, change process to a GR app that triggers MMIM enhancements.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Practice and Certification Journey
entry.content:
In today’s fast-evolving logistics industry, digital transformation and integrated systems play a critical role in ensuring efficiency, transparency, and sustainability. As someone who has received formal education in logistics and is actively continuing my professional development in this field, I strongly believe that learning SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management (TM) is a natural and strategic step in my career journey.

My motivation to learn SAP stems from my desire to deepen my understanding of logistics beyond operational processes and into system-driven decision making. Transportation Management is one of the core pillars of supply chain operations, and SAP S/4HANA TM provides an end-to-end perspective—from planning and execution to cost settlement and performance analysis. Gaining hands-on practice with this system will allow me to better understand how logistics processes are designed, optimized, and managed within global organizations.

Additionally, learning SAP S/4HANA TM will help me develop a more analytical and structured mindset. Exposure to different ERP systems not only enhances technical competence but also enables logistics professionals to think holistically, connecting operations, finance, and strategy. I believe this knowledge will significantly contribute to my ability to analyze complex logistics scenarios and propose effective, data-driven solutions.

Through SAP Practice and Certification, my goal is to strengthen my professional skill set, bridge the gap between theory and real-world applications, and position myself as a more capable and future-ready logistics profession

entry.title: Re: Password deactivation through BAPI_USER_CHANGE

for deactivating a password it is allowed exceptionally, to set LOGONDATA_CODVN and LOGONDATAX_CODVN to the value X. You need to leave all other password related fields as they are, to avoid error messages.

This exception is documented in SAP note #780485 .

entry.title: Re: Best Practice for Adjusting Project Progress Percenta...
entry.content:
Hello @Minsung_Lee 

Thank you for your question. See my response on each.

My Questions:

1. Is adjusting Plan values the correct approach for mid-project progress reconciliation, or should I be using ETC adjustments instead?

Answer: No. You should use ETC adjustments, not plan manipulation in this scenario. The standard process is a monthly review where you review your PoC and adjust the estimate to complete in the Review Customer Projects app. See Analyzing the Process Steps for Customer Project Management for more details.

2. What is the SAP-recommended standard practice for ongoing progress alignment when external progress differs from system-calculated PoC?

Answer: Revenue recognition that is event based derives cost based on PoC and it uses planned cost, actuals and your forecast values, so changing to plan just to force a percent will distort the finance logic. See Customer Projects with Event-Based Revenue Recognition.

3. Should I be using forecast month settings systematically throughout the project lifecycle rather than only at project closure?

Answer: Yes, you should use Forecast Month because, the apps evaluate KPIs and checks the deviation up to the month you forecasted for and the system determines ETC/EAC while it considers your deviations from adjustments you made in preceding periods. See KBA 3617498, Transfer Project Forecast to Finance and Review Customer Projects for more guidance.

Also, this document provides application job specifically to set the forecast month for customer projects. https://help.sap.com/doc/7c9e0bbbd1664c2581b2038a1c7ae4b3/2602.500/en-US/FSD_CE2602.pdf

I recommend you stick to the standard practice:

  1. Set Forecast Month monthly for projects.
  2. Review Customer Projects, align your process by adjusting ETC and not by changing plan.
  3. What are the risks or downstream impacts of frequently modifying Plan values vs. ETC values?
  4. Use Transfer Project Forecast to Finance to keep forecast and feed your finance.
  5. Run Event Based Revenue Recognition as per your closing cycle to post revenue based on your latest PoC and forecasts

4. What are the risks or downstream impacts of frequently modifying Plan values vs. ETC values?

Answer:

If you frequently modify your Plan values,

  • you risk blurring the meaning of plan versus baseline, budget and variance.
  • You can create misleading cost based PoC and your revenue recognitions results because plan is an input to PoC. See Customer Projects with Event-Based Revenue Recognition

Should you adjust ECT values

  • You keep plan as a planning baseline and use ETC as your operational forecast lever.
  • The system expects ETC adjustments to ensure your forecast deviations are handled across the periods. See Transfer Project Forecast to Finance and Review Customer Projects for more guidance.

Question 5 is answered with the provided references.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris
